entry.et: Middle English, from Latin socialis, from socius companion, ally, associate; akin to Old English secg man, companion, Latin sequi to follow sue

def.dt: :involving allies or confederates the Social War between the Athenians and their allies
:marked by or passed in pleasant companionship with friends or associates an active social life
:sociable
:of, relating to, or designed for sociability a social club
:of or relating to human society, the interaction of the individual and the group, or the welfare of human beings as members of society social institutions
:tending to form cooperative and interdependent relationships with others
:living and breeding in more or less organized communities social insects
:tending to grow in groups or masses so as to form a pure stand
:of, relating to, or based on rank or status in a particular society a member of our social set
:of, relating to, or characteristic of the upper classes
:formal
:being such in social situations a social drinker
:sociable
:one who attempts to gain a higher social position or acceptance in fashionable society
:an actual or hypothetical agreement among the members of an organized society or between a community and its ruler that defines and limits the rights and duties of each
:an extension of Darwinism to social phenomena

:a sociological theory that sociocultural advance is the product of intergroup conflict and competition and the socially elite classes (as those possessing wealth and power) possess biological superiority in the struggle for existence
:a political movement advocating a gradual and peaceful transition from capitalism to socialism by democratic means
:a democratic welfare state that incorporates both capitalist and socialist practices
:venereal disease
:a disease (as tuberculosis) whose incidence is directly related to social and economic factors
:management of human beings in accordance with their place and function in society :applied social science
:the application of Christian principles to social problems
:a movement in American Protestant Christianity especially in the first part of the 20th century to bring the social order into conformity with Christian principles

:protection of the individual against economic hazards (as unemployment, old age, or disability) in which the government participates or enforces the participation of employers and affected individuals
